result.execSummary:
The defendant Matthew C Blanchard was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Contributing to Truancy, a class C misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 948.45(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Marathon County Clerk of Circuit Court

supervisions.notes:
Jail with huber for employment if defendant qualifies under jail criteria and to begin within 45 days. 
Defendant is not entitled to any jail credit.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

w/Notice of Right to Seek Postconviction Relief

Clerk Marisa.
Case Called: 3:22 pm 
State appears by ADA Desiree Toldt; Def appears in person with Atty Andrew Morgan.  
Plea Quest/Waiver of Rights filed. 

State moves to: 
Ct. 2 (Felony BJ)>>D&RI. 
COURT grants above.

PLEA: Ct. 1 (Contributing to Truancy)>>NO CONTEST. 

COURT advises def of rights (including constitutional rights) & penalties & ques def to understanding.  
COURT finds plea & waiver of rights freely & vol made, a factual basis, & def guilty. 

COURT ORDERS: 12 days MCJ with huber for employment if def qualifies under jail criteria and to begin within 45 days and payment of court costs within 60 days or payment plan. 
COURT finds the def is entitled to NO days jail credit.
